sentences: Albert Salomon (Hebrew: אלברט סלומון; July 21, 1935 – November 20, 2020), also known as "Albert the Bulgarian" (Hebrew: אלברט הבולגרי), was a Bulgarian-Israeli accordion player and social activist.
Albert Salomon was born July 21, 1935 in Sofia, Bulgaria to Jacob and Regina Salomon.
In 1943, during the Holocaust, Salomon was deported to the Somovit labor camp while many of his family members were murdered.
From 1944 - 1948, Salomon was a member of the "Young Communists" in Bulgaria.
During the mass migration in 1948, Salomon immigrated to Israel through Yugoslavia along with his family and settled in Bat Yam and Jaffa where most of the Bulgarian Jews had settled.
Albert Salomon died on November 20, 2020, leaving behind three children and seven grandchildren.
A month after Salomon's death, a street party was held at his old upholstery shop location in his honor and was attended by street residents, family and friends.

At his upholstery shop in Tel Aviv, Salomon would throw street parties on a daily basis every Friday afternoon, where he would play the accordion and put out a spread of food and drinks for the homeless who were invited to attend.

In 2019, following protests against the closure of Jerusalem Avenue in Jaffa, Mayor Ron Huldai was asked about Albert Salomon (Albert the Bulgarian) who used to frequent the avenue and play his accordion.
In response, Salomon stated that it was hard for him to accept this especially since Huldai was a personal close friend and that he had lived in Tel Aviv since 1948.
